schedule.title: Ironic: Nova-compatible VNC console
schedule.description:
There are a number of proposals for new VNC console work that can integrate better with Nova and Horizon. Discuss the pros and cons of the proposals and plan a path forward.


Etherpad

schedule.title: Senlin: Work session
schedule.description:
Topic: Validate profile/policy
Description: When create a profile with wrong parameters or non-exist image id, it will still be created. But it will fail to create a node using this profile. Do we need an API for it? When talking to different service backends, we may need to validate profile/policy schemas against service API versions. We won't be creating a connection to the service before instantiating a resource. How can we do validation effectively?

schedule.title: Swift: Community Feedback and How to Contribute
schedule.description:
This fishbowl session is for the development community to discuss what's working, what's not working, and what changes we'd like to make. We'll discuss tools, meetings, communication channels, reviews, etc.

This session is also going to cover "How to Contribute" and "How to Get Started" information for new contributors in the community. In addition to reviewing the tools and docs available today, we want to hear from new contributors and find what information we need to create or make more discoverable.

schedule.title: Kolla: Adding a Kubernetes Underlay
schedule.description:
During this fishbowl session, the Kolla community will evaluate options for adding a Kubernetes underlay for Kolla containers in addition to the current orchestration provided by Ansible.


kolla-kubernetes Etherpad

schedule.title: Project Kuryr - Docker Delivered, Kubernetes Next!
schedule.description:
Kuryr was unveiled in the OpenStack Summit in Tokyo.

Its goal is to make Neutron networking available to containainers in their most widespread usages.

Kuryr's aim, as we move towards the N release, is to bridge the gap between the container orchestration engines like Kubernetes and OpenStack networking models and expose all of the production grade Neutron capabilities and services to big scale container consumers.

In this session we will talk about how Kuryr bridged the gap with Docker standalone configurations, how it brings networking to Docker Swarm and what is the roadmap for the next release.

videos.name: Project Kuryr - Docker Delivered, Kubernetes Next!

schedule.title: Infrastructure: Community Task-Tracking
schedule.description:
A status update on Storyboard and Maniphest, and the road ahead for OpenStack community task, bug and incident tracking.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-infra-community-task-tracking

schedule.title: Telco Cloud Requirements: What VNF's Are Asking For
schedule.description:
This talk will focus on the evolving requirements of current and future Telco Cloud deployments.

Network Functions are widely deployed today with quantified performance, failure and capacity requirements. As those functions make their way to a Telco Cloud, it is clear that various characteristics are required of the Cloud to preserve the brown field migration of these functions.

Requirements of Telco Cloud deployments range from high availability and liveness detection of network connectivity (PING, BFD, TCP Socket Level Checks, etc.), preserving existing network reachability with protocols such as BGP, marking tenant workload packets with correct QOS values, high I/O performance characteristics with SR-IOV/DPDK, etc.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Telco Cloud Requirements: What VNF's Are Asking For

schedule.title: Designate: Talk to the Devs
schedule.description:
We will use this session to allow other projects, users and deployers feedback into the Designate road map.

Etherpad

schedule.title: Continuously Delivering OpenStack Using OpenStack-Salt
schedule.description:
From the moment OpenStack control plane is deployed it becomes a working piece of history. Why not treat OpenStack services like set of living projects that uses the same tools the developers use to build, test and deploy your OpenStack? Openstack-salt provides model that allows to deploy security patches, bug fixes, manage service lifecycle and releases off a simple git commit. This makes your OpenStack operationally manageable once again and adding new hypervisors or entire regions is fun again. Continuous Delivery with Openstack-salt doesn't mean that every change is deployed to production right away, but means that every changes is proven and can be deployed safely at any time.

What is the problem or use case you’re addressing in this session?

How do you stay current with OpenStack? How to control operations of your OpenStack deployment.

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
schedule.description: Discussion of reference architecture of the Telemetry stack. Based on benchmarks results from gordc and llu.

schedule.title: Solinea Training: OpenStack Monitoring and Compliance
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Proactively ensuring your OpenStack cloud is performing optimally and in accordance with relevant industry compliance requirements can be a confusing and time consuming process. This two hour hands-on course will provide participants with a foundation in OpenStack monitoring and compliance. Specifically, we will explore:

OpenStack Monitoring Landscape

  • Critical Cloud elements to monitor 
  • Monitoring best practices
  • Available 3rd party tools

Logs and Events

  • Key logs and events to monitor for each OpenStack service
  • Log interpretation
  • Methods to organize and access OpenStack logs

Compliance 

  • Common compliance requirements by industry
  • Key resources for compliance
  • Technical implications of compliance

Implement a monitoring solution

  • Install Goldstone
  • Explore key logs and events in OpenStack
  • Hands on lab

schedule.title: UX OpenStack Client Study
schedule.description: client study research

schedule.title: Mirantis Two-Day Training: OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) (Day 1 of 2) - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: This training is now at MAX CAPACITY.

The OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) course https://training.mirantis.com/instructor-led-training/openstack-fuel-administration/> is a two day course that exposes participants to the required knowledge to understand and effectively leverage Mirantis' OpenStack distribution.

RSVP Required.

This training is two full-days, all day Wednesday and Thursday. Participants must attend both days in order to complete the training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

TRAINING INFO:

Install, configure, and maintain an OpenStack computing environment using Fuel The OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) course is a two day course that exposes participants to the required knowledge to understand and effectively leverage Mirantis' OpenStack distribution. Unlike our other OpenStack course offerings, the FUEL100 course focuses on the Mirantis OpenStack projects: Fuel, Murano, and Sahara. This course is designed to be complementary to the OpenStack Bootcamps and will not overlap in course material. The course focuses on the Fuel deployment environment and will give participants both the theoretical and hands-on skills required to operate Fuel to enable the deployment of OpenStack. The course is broken up into two sections: lectures and labs.

REQUIRED PRE-WORK:

VNC client such as RealVNC, UltraVNC, or TightVNC should be installed. Web browser such as Mozilla Firefox or Google Chrome should be installed.

schedule.title: SUSE Two-Day Training: OpenStack Administration - Prepare for the Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam (DAY 1 of 2)  - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: This training is now at MAX CAPACITY. 

RSVP Required

This training is two full-days, all day Wednesday and Thursday. Participants must attend both days in order to complete the training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

This course is designed for system administrators and others who want to learn how to administer an OpenStack Cloud. Participants receive a comprehensive understanding of the tasks necessary to administer an OpenStack cloud and then use common tools that are included with an OpenStack distribution to administer a SUSE OpenStack cloud. This course prepares the participants to take and pass the Certified OpenStack Administrator (COA) exam.

Agenda:

Section 1: Lab Environment Setup

Section 2: Introduction to SUSE OpenStack Cloud

Section 3: Introduction to OpenStack Cloud Administration

Section 4: Work with OpenStack Tenants

Section 5: Work with OpenStack Domains and Groups

Section 6: Work with Cloud Images

Section 7: Work with Software-defined Networks

Section 8: Work with Workload Instances

Section 9: Work with Block Storage

Section 10: Work with Object Storage

Section 11: Orchestrate the Lifecycle of Cloud Applications

Section 12: Meter Cloud Infrastructure Utilization

schedule.title: Red Hat One-Day Training: Red Hat OpenStack Platform Director
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

This training is one full day, all day Wednesday, April 27th.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

TRAINING INFO:

Red Hat OpenStack Platform director (undercloud) is a deployment and lifecycle management tool for your OpenStack environment. In this one-day course, you will learn about the architecture and technology used in the Red Hat OpenStack Platform director. You will deploy the overcloud (Red Hat OpenStack Platform installation) using the Red Hat OpenStack Platform director and expand the OpenStack deployment by adding a compute node. This is hands-on, technical training in which you will deploy the Red Hat OpenStack Platform director and verify its functionality. Attendees should have a system administration background to get the most out this training.

schedule.title: One-Day Cloud Foundry and Altoros Training: Cloud Foundry PaaS on OpenStack for DevOps Engineers
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

This training is one full day, all day Wednesday, April 27th. 

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

This full-day training is intended for DevOps engineers who want to learn how to create, configure, and support a production-grade Cloud Foundry cluster with services on OpenStack. It provides the knowledge necessary to build a PaaS and start using it for hosting real-life apps.

The lectures and demos are designed to help DevOps engineers to:
-understand essential cloud concepts (IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS)
-get familiar with Cloud Foundry architecture (components, buildpacks, stacks, domains, routes, and services)
-learn how to set up, configure, and administer their own Cloud Foundry cluster on OpenStack (zero-downtime updates and scaling; orgs/spaces/roles/permissions, user management, logging and metrics)
-learn how to use the Cloud Foundry CLI (basic concepts, pushing apps, getting logs, scaling, stopping/starting, changing/adding routes, etc.)
-understand how to setup and use Cloud Foundry services on OpenStack (standard services shipped with CF, user-provided services, and managed services)

schedule.title: Rackspace One-Day Training: OpenStack Unpacked - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: This training is now at MAX CAPACITY.

RSVP Required

This training is one full day, all day Wednesday, April 27th.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

OpenStack Unpacked is a course designed for newcomers, both technical and non-technical. This course will introduce you to OpenStack through hands on labs, lectures and in class coaching. Attendees who may be unfamiliar with working on the command line, using API’s or OpenStack in general, will feel comfortable in this environment. Our experienced instructors will guide you step by step to help build your confidence and knowledge surrounding OpenStack. After this course, you will be able to talk OpenStack fluently and also have some hands on experience to back it up.

schedule.title: Neutron DSCP: Policing your Network
schedule.description: DSCP is used by large enterprises to manage network traffic intelligently. It provides quality of service to enable traffic engineering, and in some cases can additionally be relied on to enforce network security policies. The inclusion of DSCP in Newton Neutron now makes this facility available to all users, from individuals to large enterprises. This talk will describe DSCP for those unfamiliar with it, discuss how DSCP is used ‘in the wild’ today, and relate the path taken to deliver the Open vSwitch-based reference implementation for Newton.

videos.name: Neutron DSCP: Policing your Network

schedule.title: Mesos and OpenStack: The Perfect Tag Team for Containers
schedule.description:
Container Orchestration Engines such as Kubernetes and Swarm provide full management for containers, however they assume that the cluster infrastructure is provided by someone else. OpenStack provides the full infrastructure and Magnum integrates these resources for the Container Orchestration Engine, but the resource management is left to the users. Mesos on the other hand provides advanced, highly scalable resource management.

Recent development allows Kubernetes and Swarm to run on Mesos as frameworks. This makes it now possible to bring the 3 layers together to achieve a new level of integration and automation, yielding many benefits: scaling at both the container and the node level, fine grained resource sharing among clusters, etc.

In this talk, we will take a close look at running Kubernetes and Swarm workloads on Mesos, hosted on OpenStack. We will show the necessary plumbing for the integration, and discuss potential issues in providing networking and storage through Mesos.

videos.name: Mesos and OpenStack: The Perfect Tag Team for Containers

schedule.title: Deploying OpenStack-Ansible - The Quick and Dirty Guide
schedule.description:
Deploying OpenStack is hard, deploying OpenStack with the openstack-ansible project is less hard... We would like to show you how you can make it even easier and address some of the problems and questions that we get regarding deploying OpenStack using openstack-ansible.

This will include:

  • A general 'how to' starting from initial basic setup, to expanding your deployment.
  • How, and where to make configuration changes.
  • What to do when openstack-ansible does not support your customization.
  • Tips and tricks to help you with openstack-ansible.
  • How to build on your openstack-ansible deployment with custom components.
  • Where to go for help.

videos.name: Deploying OpenStack-Ansible - The Quick and Dirty Guide

schedule.title: Stateless Hypervisors at Scale, We'll Do It Live!
schedule.description: In this presentation we will introduce a method of booting Nova hypervisors over the network into a stateless live booted operating system. By using a live operating system, we separate the stateless operating system running in RAM from the Nova configuration and instance data which is persistent on disk. Because the OS is an image, it's easier to jump across versions as you can load the latest version of the OS by either doing a reboot or a kexec. It also helps maintain consistency and ensures that whenever a machine goes down for maintenance or a reboot, it will come back on the latest and greatest build. We'll touch on how the OS can be maintained using Git and how CI/CD can be utilized to automatically generate the latest version of the build and deploy it.

videos.name: Stateless Hypervisors at Scale, We'll Do It Live!

schedule.title: Deploying OpenStack for The National Science Foundation's Newest Supercomputers
schedule.description: The National Science Foundation has recently funded two high performance computing resources powered by OpenStack.  The Bridges machine at Pittsburgh Super Computing Center and Jetstream at Indiana University/Texas Advanced Computing Center comprise a combined $16.2 million dollar investment in 18 petabytes of storage, 40864 processor cores,and  354 terabytes of memory.  The architecture, performance, use cases, and deployment details of each of these two machines will be covered.

videos.name: Deploying OpenStack for The National Science Foundation's Newest Supercomputers

schedule.title: Distributed NFV & OpenStack: Challenges and Potential Solutions
schedule.description:
Review and proposed next steps for challenges BT found with OpenStack for Distributed NFV use cases. At SDN World Congress last year, Peter Willis of British Telecom presented a set of challenges that are preventing BT from using OpenStack for Distributed NFV deployments – specifically for virtual CPE or vBranch use case. 

This session will explore more about the challenges and attempts to identify near-term and long-term solutions. The solutions will range from creative ways of leveraging Linux capabilities, selective use of OpenStack, and other open source projects like OpenDayLight in the short term and identify promising OpenStack blueprints and projects for longer-term solutions.

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Distributed NFV & OpenStack: Challenges and Potential Solutions

schedule.title: Openstack Components as Containerized MicroServices
schedule.description:
Openstack is already an ecosystem designed with microservices in mind. Now its time to start using it is designed. By deploying openstack components with a microservice architecture in mind it will allow you to scale, recover from disasters, redeploy and upgrade with ease.

Containerizing this micro services will provide you an easy way to test and even deploy from the latest and greatest code from community, allowing you to test many new features before you need to roll them out to you production cloud.

videos.name: Openstack Components as Containerized MicroServices

schedule.title: Zaqar Messaging for Microservices and IoT
schedule.description: One of the challenges that users face when developing an application using a microservices architecture is how to distribute information between each microservice. Similar challenges can be seen in IoT and sensor applications - how can you efficiently receive data from huge numbers of devices? For the purpose of our presentation we developed a demo on resolving these communication and distribution problems using Zaqar, OpenStack’s Messaging and Notification service.

videos.name: Zaqar Messaging for Microservices and IoT

schedule.title: Swift Object Encryption
schedule.description:
A new feature in development for OpenStack Swift improves security by encrypting object data at rest.

OpenStack Swift provides reliable and scalable object storage that has been deployed in many successful production environments. The Swift developer community has recently been working on enhancing Swift’s security by adding the capability to encrypt object content stored on disk. Our goal is to protect data at rest from an attacker that gains physical access to disks. We aim to achieve this with complete transparency to clients i.e. with no API changes, other than optional extensions to support client provided keys when desired.

This talk will describe and demonstrate this exciting new feature, discuss options for integration with key management services such as Barbican, and look ahead at future work to additionally encrypt account and container metadata.

videos.name: Swift Object Encryption

schedule.title: Getting Started With OpenStack
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

OpenStack continues to grow as the de facto standard for open source Cloud platforms and private clouds in general. But how can someone quickly get started with learning this technology? This workshop will walk participants through an overview of the most deployed OpenStack components and offer practical suggestions and resources for learning OpenStack.

As part of this workshop, we will assist attendees with deploying a test OpenStack instance on their laptops using Vagrant, VirtualBox, and RDO. The relevant Vagrant file and pre-workshop instructions will be included in the final abstract if this workshop is approved. We will then walk attendees through the horizon dashboard and the OpenStack CLI to manage and use their new OpenStack instance.

----------------------------------------------------

Before you arrive at this session please complete the "Preparation" 
section of these instructions: 
https://radez.fedorapeople.org/GettingStartedWithOpenStack.html 


It will take some time and bandwidth, please plan accordingly.

videos.name: Getting Started With OpenStack

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: EMC - Accelerated cloud native application development
schedule.description: Getting an application development environment up and running on top of OpenStack can be challenging and time consuming. How to reduce time to code? How do you deploy and scale applications with ease? How do you leverage containers to develop micro services? Do you have to choose between structured & unstructured PaaS? How do you integrate your cloud-native platform into existing enterprise operational systems? We will show how EMC’s turn-key OpenStack powered appliance addresses these issues and enables you to start developing cloud native applications in a matter of hours.

videos.name: EMC - Accelerated cloud native application development

schedule.title: Trove: Work session
schedule.description:
Trove Newton Design Summit Overview
http://bit.ly/trove-newton-design-summit

schedule.title: Magnum: Work session
schedule.description:
This session will discuss how to support lifecycle management for long running bays. In particular, the following areas will be explored:
* Support upgrade of individual components of running bays.
* Dynamically reconfigure existing bays.
* Automate fault detection and recovery for bays.
* Prevent privilege escalation of individual bays.

This work session should cover API v2 discussions: current implementation status, plans, details.
Etherpad

schedule.description:
More detailed discussion and review on upcoming features including the following:

1. Multiple metrics (group_by)

2. Non-periodic metrics

6. others...

schedule.description:

Work out what needs to be done to have Ubuntu 16.04 support in conjunction with Ubuntu 14.04 support. The intended outcome of the session is to have at least one OpenStack service role fully implemented for Ubuntu 14.04 and 16.04 and passing a functional gate test.

Etherpad for the Work Session

schedule.description:

schedule.title: Business Cloud Advisor - Enterprise Strategies for Cloud Adoption
schedule.description: Enterprises are increasingly adopting cloud to support digital transfomation. We will deep dive into cloud adoption strategies, maturity levels, specific, common use cases while taking a broad view of IT strategy, architecture, and organizational design. From collective discussion, we will build roadmap for a public, private and hybrid cloud journey leveraging best practices, common techniques, lessons learned and real-world examples from OpenStack adoptors.

schedule.description:
Testing and CI (moderator: gampel)
--------------------

Multi driver DB CI testing etcd,redis,zookepper, ramcloud
Multi driver PubSub CI test

schedule.description: A lot of progress was made toward supporting A/A in Mitaka. Discuss current state and next steps to move this forward.

Replacing/Augmenting MiniDNS with Go.

This session will be looking at what needs to be done to move MiniDNS to a go based binary.

Etherpad

schedule.title: Ironic: Status and future of our gate
schedule.description:
There are a number of ongoing changes and plans for our CI gate. Catch up on the status of that work and some plans to improve it this cycle.

Etherpad

schedule.title: Senlin: Work session
schedule.description:
Topic: Better Distribution
Driver: Elynn
Description:
- Use tooz as distributed lock management?
tooz is a DLM tool, by using it we can easily implement lock between multi engines. but it depends on existing tools like zookeeper, redis etc. If we introduce tooz, we might need to depend on these 3 party tools, how do we constraint the scope of tooz in senlin engine. Need to consider license issue, CI issue etc.
- Should we bring distributed key-value store as the database backends?
- Any other blocking issues when scaling senlin-engine and senlin-api?

schedule.title: Swift: Ops Feedback
schedule.description: This fishbowl session is for Swift deployers to tell the developers what's working, what's not working, and what's the most important to work on. We want to hear about pain points, especially around deployment and operational tooling.

schedule.title: Kolla: Operational Pain Points
schedule.description:
During IRC evaluations of Kolla, the Kolla community typically asks the question 'What are the top 3 pain points when using Kolla". In Liberty deployments this was all over the place. Individuals evaluating Mitaka don't really have any significant reports of pain points. I'd like to validate the assumption "All of the pain points are resolved." The objective of this fishbowl session is to uncover unknown pain points the Kolla community can address in the upcoming Newton cycle.




Pain Points Etherpad

schedule.title: Scality - Six Years OpenStack, What’s Next? Featuring Marc Shuttleworth (Canonical), Steve Muir (Comcast), Jerome Lecat (Scality), and Ashish Nadkarni (IDC)
schedule.description:
It was in the Austin Convention center that OpenStack was first announced in July 2010 by the Rackspace marketing team.

It was in the Austin Convention center that OpenStack was first announced in July 2010 by the Rackspace marketing team. The OpenStack project was started to help organizations build cloud-computing services leveraging standard hardware. The community's first official release appeared four months later. In 2011, developers of the Ubuntu Linux distribution adopted OpenStack. Ubuntu's sponsor Canonical then introduced full support for OpenStack clouds.\n\nIn the years to come, OpenStack would become the biggest open source initiative since Linux, supported by a fast-growing community. A recent major breakthrough came in August 2015, when Platform9 announced that its OpenStack distribution was fully interoperable with VMware vSphere.

Join us for - and participate in - an exciting panel with Canonical's Marc Shuttleworth, Scality's Jerome Lecat, Matthew Curley from HPE and Steve Muir from Comcast, moderated by Ashish Nadkarni from IDC. The panelists will give their views on the past and future of OpenStack: what have we achieved so far, where are we going and most importantly, how will users benefit from the community's efforts?

The OpenStack project was started to help organizations build cloud-computing services leveraging standard hardware. The community's first official release appeared four months later. In 2011, developers of the Ubuntu Linux distribution adopted OpenStack. Ubuntu's sponsor Canonical then introduced full support for OpenStack clouds.

In the years to come, OpenStack would become the biggest open source initiative since Linux, supported by a fast-growing community. A recent major breakthrough came in August 2015, when Platform9 announced that its OpenStack distribution was fully interoperable with VMware vSphere.

Join us for - and participate in - an exciting panel with Canonical's Marc Shuttleworth, Scality's Jerome Lecat, Matthew Curley from HPE and Steve Muir from Comcast, moderated by Ashish Nadkarni from IDC. The panelists will give their views on the past and future of OpenStack: what have we achieved so far, where are we going and most importantly, how will users benefit from the community's efforts?

videos.name: Scality - Six Years OpenStack, What’s Next? Featuring Marc Shuttleworth (Canonical), Steve Muir (Comcast), Jerome Lecat (Scality), and Ashish Nadkarni (IDC)

schedule.title: QA: Devstack Roadmap
schedule.description:
Quick update on the progress of the Neutron refactor, discuss some of the issues discovered while doing the refactor, and plans to finish the refactor.

Session Leader: Sean M. Collins, Sean Dague

Etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-qa-devstack-roadmap

schedule.title: Freezer: Backup / Restore an OpenStack infrastructure
schedule.description:
Let's discuss how we can leverage Freezer to backup/restore a full OpenStack Infrastructure.


We will focus on defining all components that need to be backed up and how to achieve an efficient restore.
The idea is to come up with a list of missing features that will be implemented in the future.

Etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/freezer_austin_session_backup_os_infra

schedule.title: Project Vitrage: How to Organize, Analyze and Visualize your OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
When problems or strange behaviors emerge in a complex cloud environment, it's difficult to understand what is causing them, making the management of such systems untenable.

The Vitrage project is designed to address precisely this.

Vitrage is a new Root Cause Analysis Engine for organizing, analyzing and expanding OpenStack alarms & events, yielding insights regarding the root cause of problems and deducing the existence of problems before they are directly detected.

Its ultimate goal is that every significant occurrence in the cloud should have a timely alarm generated for it, and that the cause-effect relationships between these events is understood and visualized.

In this session we'll present Vitrage for the first time. In addition to going over its goals, design and planned features, we will demo three features supported for the Mitaka version of Vitrage:

1. A clear view of the Cloud Topology

2. Configurable template-based raising of alarms

3. The Root Cause Analysis of these alarms

videos.name: Project Vitrage: How to Organize, Analyze and Visualize your OpenStack Cloud

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
schedule.description:
Gnocchi, the next steps.

Let's take some time to discuss where the project is, what it's solving currently, and what it's gonna solve next.

Feedback welcome!

schedule.title: NetApp - I want it now!  Or, doing more with less for accelerating application development for Developers.
schedule.description: TBA

videos.name: NetApp - I want it now!  Or, doing more with less for accelerating application development for Developers.

schedule.title: Oculus for OpenStack Ops (OpenStack Goes 3D)
schedule.description:
OpenStack Horizon, command-line clients and API libraries let developers and operators interact directly, indirectly, and automatically with a target cloud. Analytics tools like Stacklight (LMA toolchain) give deeper insight with sophisticated interactive graphics and out-of-band interaction channels like Nagios alerts. Beyond these tools, however, lies a new world of VR-based immersive UX for operations, visualization and collaboration.

In this session, we’ll discuss:

  • Open-source toolchain options for building immersive UX around cloud computing
  • UI widgets, DevOps and dataviz metaphors (from skeuomorphism to … beyond!)
  • The Internet of Things (to Visualize): VR + OpenStack + IoT = Value
  • How to build your own Minority Report-style UI (with no Tom Cruise in it)

And demonstrate a virtual-reality collaborative OpenStack operations environment compatible with Oculus Rift.

videos.name: Oculus for OpenStack Ops (OpenStack Goes 3D)

schedule.title: OpenStack at Scale inside NetApp: Trials and Tribulations
schedule.description:
Want to hear from how we've implemented OpenStack internally inside our engineering support organization?  How we're able to scale to over 7000 VM instances, 14,000 cores across 3 geographical regions (2 US, 1 India)?  Also how we're able to automate upgrades with Puppet between releases for a non-disruptive experience for our users?   If so, this session is for you! 

We will focus on a couple of key findings:

What influence the needs of our users had on the choice of the underlying compute, storage and networking layer

What challenges we faced when combining this new self-service environment with best practices of traditional IT and virtualization, with a focus on automation and ease-of-use for both our developers and our operators

How OpenStack challenges the status quo of support organizations, and where we are taking our internal deployment next

Tips for selecting and sourcing optimal hardware for OpenStack deployments, with reference architecture advice on optimal deployments

videos.name: OpenStack at Scale inside NetApp: Trials and Tribulations

schedule.title: High-Performance OpenStack for Science and Data Analytics in a Hybrid Cloud Environment
schedule.description: Traditionally, high-performance science and data analytics workloads have been run on specialized clusters tailored to a small number of applications.  OpenStack provides a superior cloud platform that not only accommodates a wider range of applications than specialized clusters but also reduces costs by running steady state workloads on-premise while providing the ability to “burst” into a variety of off-premise clouds.  This session details technology and architectures to optimize OpenStack for technical and data-intensive computing as well as techniques for tailoring HPC workloads for better portability and performance on private and public cloud platforms.  Lastly, we cover case studies that demonstrate how research organizations leverage OpenStack to address these issues in pursuit of their life-changing missions.

videos.name: High-Performance OpenStack for Science and Data Analytics in a Hybrid Cloud Environment

schedule.title: Service Function Chaining – Technology Analysis and Perspective
schedule.description:
Service chaining plays an important role in network function virtualization by stitching together an ordered list of virtual network functions, such as routers, firewalls, load balancers etc., to achieve a particular complex service that previously required multiple physical appliances. This presentation will review and analyze two major technologies that enable service function chaining, i.e. NSH-based SFC and BGPVPN-based SFC, followed by current status of various projects addressing SFC, MPLS / BGP VPN, and related APIs in OPNFV, OpenStack and Open Daylight. Lastly, this presentation will also review a prior PoC that implemented inter-DC SFC using BGPVPN technology.

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Service Function Chaining – Technology Analysis and Perspective

schedule.title: Among the Cloud: Open Source NFV + SDN deployment
schedule.description:
Panel discussion

Moderator: Neela Jacques

Panelists: Chris Price (OPNFV); Colin Dixon (ODL); Margaret Chiosi (AT&T); Alex Zhang (China Mobile)

Seven years after the launch of SDN and the development of OpenFlow, SDN and NFV are changing the networking landscape. NFV is quickly going from white paper to POC to deployment and a dominant stack is emerging. Dozens of new products are being released based on open innovation and cloud-based deployments are on the rise. Hear  industry experts discuss the latest new SDN and NFV use cases, how SDN and NFV impact cloud deployments, the evolution of the end user and what’s on the horizon.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Among the Cloud: Open Source NFV + SDN deployment

schedule.title: Building Real-Time Cloud Using OpenStack
schedule.description: Users or operators sometimes need to run low-latency or real-time applications (such as audio/video streaming, highly interactive systems, etc.) to meet their requirements in clouds,  and in fact it seems that it is one of the reasons why people need to use Ironic on OpenStack, although Ironic lacks management advantage of virtualization. And a good news is that we have sufficient infrastructure to achieve that in OpenStack (in the M release). With these features, OpenStack can host low-latency or real-time applications without using Ironic. However, it’s still cumbersome to configure and build such real-time clouds.Since we are working on Real-time KVM as one of the projects of KVM enhancements for NFV at OPNFV, we share our know-how and experiences to build real-time clouds using OpenStack.In this session, we will show how to configure Nova nodes (CPU, I/O, memory, etc.) and root-cause potential problems with real-time applications on OpenStack.

videos.name: Building Real-Time Cloud Using OpenStack

schedule.title: OpenStack Operation Under a Multi-Tenant and Multi-Customer Public Cloud Environment
schedule.description: We at NTT Communications have recently launched the public/hosted private cloud service "Enterprise Cloud 2.0" with OpenStack Juno. Since the main target users are Enterprise users, there were some gaps between the OpenStack community version and what the user wants. To fill in the gaps (e.g. VM is required more reliability, connection with multiple NW gw's needs to be automated), we have designed an architecture with Virtual Machine High Availability (VM-HA) function, specialized virtualized network (ESI, Elastic Service Infrastructure), and developed operation tools, which can scale out the number of cases our operation engineers can handle. We will share the operation design and knowledge to operate OpenStack under this kind of environment, which is multi-tenant and multi-customer. We will also share the shift in thinking from our experience of having operated another Cloud management platform.

videos.name: OpenStack Operation Under a Multi-Tenant and Multi-Customer Public Cloud Environment

schedule.title: Troubleshoot Cloud Networking Like a Pro
schedule.description: OpenStack is a large cloud platform, which can be configured, used and be broken innumerable ways. On the other hand configure networking is usually tricky especially in a large environment both with OpenStack or in general, so most probably you asked the question "Why is my networking not working?" several times already in your life. In this presentation we are going to describe the common problems that can occur and we will list different techniques and systematic approaches to find the solutions to these issues. Whether you are beginner or advanced, if you are struggling much with networking in your cloud, join us to learn new solutions or just to bring home a good troubleshooting guide.

videos.name: Troubleshoot Cloud Networking Like a Pro

schedule.title: Multi-tenancy for Docker Containers With Keystone, and Adding Quota Limits
schedule.description:
Docker containers need multi-tenancy feature with keystone which will help to isolate the containers for different users and tenants. Multi tenancy will avoid users invading other users' containers, since the containers owned will be invisible to other tenants or users except the admin or the owner of the containers.

The proposed approach enables the organization administrator to specify quota limits through keystone ensuring budget targets are adhered to in a pay-as-you-go pricing model. Use keystone to validate the identity of a user's username-password, API key or authentication token.

Proposal is to create a new authentication plugin to talk to keystone and validate the user's credentials.

This security feature allows secure communications between containers. The private networking enables open connectivity within the environment deployed by a given user.

videos.name: Multi-tenancy for Docker Containers With Keystone, and Adding Quota Limits

schedule.title: Live Migrating Nova-Networking to Neutron in Icehouse
schedule.description:
Nova-networking has been a staple of Openstack since nearly the beginning. Still in use by many organizations, it is stable and well tested. As organizations continue to move to a more feature-rich network orchestration framework, Nova-networking is no longer meeting their needs, and Neutron is the future. Unfortunately, there's no clear migration strategy for moving from Nova-networking to Neutron.

In this talk we will:

  • Detail our migration of several live Icehouse environments running nova-networking with the linuxbridge plugin and VLAN network segmentation over to Neutron
  • Share the code and documentation written to achieve this with minimal tenant impact, and
  • Answer questions anyone may have

Migrating from legacy code is always a tough proposition, but by tackling it together it's one which doesn't have to be insurmountable.

videos.name: Live Migrating Nova-Networking to Neutron in Icehouse

schedule.title: RBAC with Apache Fortress and IDM Using Midpoint

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: Datera - OpenStack Cinder delivering Intent-Defined Infrastructure
schedule.description: OpenStack provides an ubiquitous platform for application deployment and scaling. However, for stateful applications the ability to scale is physically bound to the infrastructure capabilities. There is a need to define the application requirements through clean contracts and abstractions to the infrastructure. The underlying infrastructure should translate this intent to best address the requirements for the application. In this session, we present an implementation to enable intent-defined storage for OpenStack through the notion of application templates.

videos.name: Datera - OpenStack Cinder delivering Intent-Defined Infrastructure

schedule.title: Appformix - The Neighbors Aren't Noisy Anymore
schedule.description:
AppFormix and Intel collaborated to solve the noisy neighbor problem that's become a bigger issue in private cloud than anyone thought it would be. Increasingly dense core counts and the rise of microservices mean that a resource-greedy VM or container will jeopardize the performance of your well-behaved workloads.In this talk you'll learn how AppFormix software has been integrated into Intel Resource Director Technology to deliver performance improvements of more than 50%. It's a real-time monitoring stack for the next generation. Come find out how it keeps noisy neighbors in check.

AppFormix and Intel collaborated to solve the noisy neighbor problem that's become a bigger issue in private cloud than anyone thought it would be. Increasingly dense core counts and the rise of microservices mean that a resource-greedy VM or container will jeopardize the performance of your well-behaved workloads.In this talk you'll learn how AppFormix software has been integrated into Intel Resource Director Technology to deliver performance improvements of more than 50%. It's a real-time monitoring stack for the next generation. Come find out how it keeps noisy neighbors in check.

videos.name: Appformix - The Neighbors Aren't Noisy Anymore

schedule.title: EMC - Resilient, geo-distributed persistence for SWIFT data
schedule.description: Data is increasingly becoming the crown jewel for most businesses. Data loss can not only result in massive competitive disadvantages, but heavy penalties if compliance, regulatory or policy mandates are violated. As you deploy new apps on OpenStack, you can de-couple your data to a resilient, persistent storage fully compliant with OpenStack Swift to focus on your application without worrying about the data. Ever wonder what a persistent SWIFT store would look like? Check out a demonstration of ECS, an object store that works well with Keystone, S3 and Hadoop. It can also replicate across geographies. AND it accepts and translates NFS files.

videos.name: EMC - Resilient, geo-distributed persistence for SWIFT data

schedule.title: Horizon: Work session
schedule.description:
Packaging / Dependency handling

- How plugins should consume Horizon (separate Horizon lib for example)

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/horizon-newton-packaging

schedule.title: Fuel: Work session
schedule.description:
Title: Finalizing of HA reference architecture with event-based control and fencing
Session lead: V. Kuklin
Etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/fuel-ha-finalization-session
Agenda:
- Switching to latest Corosync and Pacemaker versions - what's new in there, what we can use:
-- Multi-DC clusters - managing with Booth project
-- Advanced management of quorum voting - use quorumtool for cluster LCM scenarios
-- Steps to port fencing topology management for Puppet from Fuel fencing plugin
- Power Management feature-set
-- Which framework to use to store PM credentials - Ironic/fuel infra pxetool/etc.
-- How to serialize data for Pacemaker fencing configuration
- StackLight and Monitoring integration
-- Node health status integral value - How to calculate it
-- Integration of health value with Pacemaker - when to fence, when to shut services gracefully
-- Anomaly detection - how to do it and how to classify anomalies
-- Which events to fire depending on the anomaly type
- Stateful services HA improvements
-- Galera
-- RabbitMQ
-- Mongo
- Stateless services HA improvements
-- Switching to nginx for load-balancing and proxying
-- Disable/enable/maintenance mode for services during cluster LCM operations
- HA testing
-- OCF testing and CI
-- Jepsen framework integration

schedule.title: Magnum: Work session
schedule.description:
This session will discuss how to improve the scalability of Magnum. For example, how to make Magnum run hundreds of bays and thousands of containers? A direction could be supporting asynchronous operations to increase the system throughput. In particular, there is a spec [1] to propose asynchronous operations for containers. This session might discuss the spec.
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/275003/

schedule.title: Ceph and The Future of Storage
schedule.description: The Ceph project invites storage professionals, developers, and existing Ceph users to discuss their experiences, best practices, and lessons learned around storage and OpenStack. After a brief update on the current state of Ceph development, we will explore the current status of distributed storage, both in general and as it relates to the cloud.

schedule.title: Glance: Work session
schedule.description:
Shared session:
1. Categorized configuration options with sensible defaults: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-glance-categorized-configuration
2. Glance + Microversions: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-glance-microversions

schedule.title: How to Architect Applications for the Cloud
schedule.description:
Engage and enable enterprise development teams to realize the value from cloud architecture and accelerate cloud application while enabling solutions that work on any client platform.  In this session we will provide an overview of how to design applications for the cloud and provide lessons learned from a customer who has 800+ applications in various stages of development and deployment.  The session will cover architecture design decisions, key things to consider for integration with existing application, design patterns, code samples, and best practices for developing cloud aware applications and supporting business strategy for modern application development (cloud, mobile/multi-OS, application security, and improved user experience).

Deploying a cloud infrastructure is only the first step in realizing the business value. Engaging the application development teams is critical with solutions that address the business problems enterprises are facing with security, multiple client platform support, and cloud integration. Within Intel IT our original cloud specific approach stalled our cloud adoption for almost 2 years, first issue centered on the application architecture and the second primarily because of integration with existing solutions and services. We will share the challenges and approaches, development practices and technologies used to accelerate modern application solutions and cloud deployment.

videos.name: How to Architect Applications for the Cloud

schedule.title: Chasing the Rainbow – National Computational Infrastructure’s Pursuit of High-Performance OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
With a mission to foster ambitious and aspirational research objectives, the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) in Australia is building world-class computing services through a collaboration of national organizations and research-intensive universities.As an increasing number of applications such as bioinformatics start to leverage Big Data, and more virtual laboratories call for self-service and research results sharing, it becomes apparent for NCI that a high performance cloud is needed. This cloud must combine the virtues of cloud to support multi-tenancy, self-service and Big Data type of applications, and of HPC to support compute-intensive parallel.

In this presentation, NCI and Mellanox will join hands to discuss the various approaches experimented to construct a high-performance cloud, comparison of the pros and cons of each of the approaches, preliminary performance results, and the role of high-speed network for enhancing cloud performance and efficiency.

videos.name: Chasing the Rainbow – National Computational Infrastructure’s Pursuit of High-Performance OpenStack Cloud

schedule.title: Monasca: Work session
schedule.description:
The Logging API has undergone a lot of development over the last few months and is ready for deployment. In this session we'll discuss what's next in the Monasca Logging Service and how to coordinate and plan efforts. Topics include the following:

1. Query API

2. Logstash Agent

3. Beaver Agent

4. Logstash components

5. and more

schedule.title: Glance and SLURM: User-Defined Image Management on HPC Clusters
schedule.description:
Los Alamos National Laboratory has developed software that enables users to execute a user-defined software stack (UDSS) as part of a normal HPC batch job. Glance is used for UDSS image management. A SLURM plugin was written to interface the resource manager with Glance to deploy the requested UDSS image to the user's allocated job nodes. I will describe how this plugin works and give a short demonstration of its use.

LA-UR-16-20535

videos.name: Glance and SLURM: User-Defined Image Management on HPC Clusters

schedule.title: Cinder: Mitaka Recap, Part 1
schedule.description:
A lot changed that developers need to be aware of. The plan is to have part presentation, part discussion to make sure everyone is aware of changes, knows what to look out for in reviews, and understands any new restrictions.

Topics:
Microversions for developing new functionality
scottda will lead this presentation
* What's implemented
* How it should be used
* Do's and Dont's
* Example of implementing it in one API

Conditional DB updates for developing new functionality and making changes to the API
geguileo will lead this presentation
* What's implemented
* Advanced functionality
- Using DB fields instead of reading the data and changing it
- Easily joining multiple tables
- etc.
* Things that cannot be done because one of supported SQL engines does not support it

Rolling upgrades for developing new functionality
geguileo and dulek will lead this presentation
*devref patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279186/ ). <-- This is what I was hopping for ;-)
* What's implemented and what not (post install migrations)
* Do's and dont's when creating new patches
- For example you cannot directly drop a field that is already in use, you need 1 release in between
- Renaming a field requires 3 releases, and it must be done in a specific way
- If a versioned object changes it needs to be careful with the obj_make_compatible
* Example of changes

schedule.description:

Plugin Planning Etherpad

schedule.title: Scality - Open Networking and SDS, vendor-level integration amplifies Software Defined Convergence
schedule.description:
Open Networking with Software-Defined Storage allows for the freedom of selection of hardware and software. Leveraging the open platform model on bare-metal switches and servers, the unified network and storage solution allows common automation, management and monitoring framework.

Open Networking with Software-Defined Storage allows for the freedom of selection of hardware and software. Leveraging the open platform model on bare-metal switches and servers, the unified network and storage solution allows common automation, management and monitoring framework. Join Scality and Cumulus as we discuss the benefits of deploying Open Networking and Software-Defined Storage on an open platform. See how these new models address the daily challenges encountered by modern enterprises such as common management and monitoring tools, convenient locality solutions, and automatic load balancing.

Join Scality and Cumulus as we discuss the benefits of deploying Open Networking and Software-Defined Storage on an open platform. See how these new models address the daily challenges encountered by modern enterprises such as common management and monitoring tools, convenient locality solutions, and automatic load balancing.

schedule.title: NetApp - Skyrocketing Development & Deployment with OpenStack and Docker : The What, Why, and How. "Handling DevOps Challenges During the Lifecycle of an Application"
schedule.description:
From concept to production deployment, there are many, many challenges that developers and operators face. Repeatability, scale of testing, deployment, updates, etc. are all issues that must be dealt with along the path to production deployment. Using real-world examples and demonstrations, we will go through how you can integrate Docker containers and OpenStack technologies to solve these problems. Along the way, we will show how you can avoid pain points and show you examples of getting past common hurdles. See how OpenStack and Docker can meet your business and operational goals by accelerating and simplifying the DevOps process.

You will:

  • See how development teams can dramatically speed up the application-development lifecycle: from fetching work-environments to scaling out in deployment.
  • Learn how to make backups, cloning, and other data-related processes both easy and efficient.

videos.name: NetApp - Skyrocketing Development & Deployment with OpenStack and Docker : The What, Why, and How. "Handling DevOps Challenges During the Lifecycle of an Application"

schedule.title: Diversity Working Group
schedule.description:
Please join us for discussion on diversity topics in OpenStack community.

Topics: Diversity working group update 

How you can help

In Vancouver the OpenStack Board chartered a work group to explore and foster a diverse OpenStack Community. The basis for this is the belief that enlisting the broadest set of viewpoints and experience will enable us to create the most innovative and impactful technologies in support of the OpenStack Mission.

A broad set of community members formed the Diversity Work Group that has worked over the last year to form a framework for a diverse community through the creation of a Diversity Policy, integrated Diversity expectations into our Code of Conducts and identified initial areas of focus for extending the diversity of our community. Please come join us to discuss the team’s work and shape the future direction.

Additional speakers: Carol Barrett and Kavit Munshi.

schedule.title: Join the cloud app training community - help others learn how to make apps for the cloud!
schedule.description:
Currently, the no.1 problem facing OpenStack developers is the "cambrian explosion" in cloud application paradigms (Containers, SDKs, APIs, VMs, Orchestration... oh my!). DevOpps and AppDev communities have significantly different views on the ways in which to develop cloud apps, let alone *what* a 'cloud app' is?!.

The community needs a place to learn about each other's cloud application techniques. 
This workshop will bring together coders who are responsible for training new users in cloud application paradigms. This community will be focused on helping the humans whom live outside of the OpenStack community and are looking for how best to host their apps on OpenStack.

People who should attend this workshop:

  • Staff responsible for providing training on how to use / deploy / create apps on OpenStack, i.e. Mirantis DevOpps showing their customer AppDev how to deploy apps.
  • External cloud app developer communities, i.e. Ruby AppDev looking to deploy their apps via Fog on AWS, Azure and Rackspace.
  • Legacy and enterprise app developers, i.e. cloud aware apps utilising APIs to bridge scalable cloud compute/data services.
  • Container developers, i.e. CoreOS/Docker applications being orchestrated by K8S.
  • Any technically savvy person who like to help other learn about cloud apps, i.e. DevOpps who speak AppDev, and vice versa.

Objectives (by the end of this workshop you will know how to...):

  • Run cloud application training which utilises best practice in learning science (aka pedagogical intelligences[1]), i.e. friends don't let friends kill each other with powerpoint.
  • Provide a training forum where multiple developers audiences (SysAdmin, DevOpps, AppDev, TestEng & UXer) can learn and train one another about good practice in cloud applications.
  • Craft learning challenges (problem-sets) for varying skill levels and cloud application paradigms: cloud native apps (containers, docker, coreos), cloud aware apps (ProgLang specific SDKs, LibCloud, jCloud, Fog, etc.), cloud organic apps (APIs, VMs, etc.) and orchestrating cloud apps (HeAT, K8S, Swarm, Rkt, etc).
  • Share cloud application learning challenges in a fun and community driven way so that all can benefit from better cloud application development.

Outline of this training avaialble here: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/train-the-trainer-cloud-apps

Pre-Recorded version of this training here (please contact Flanders@OpenStack.org to join this community):https://youtu.be/yDTtK9cJqBc

[1]= Pedagogical techniques utilised: "Problem Based Learning" & "Participatory Learning" (see Wikipedia).

videos.name: Join the cloud app training community - help others learn how to make apps for the cloud!

schedule.title: Using Ceilometer Data for Effective Witch-Hunting
schedule.description:
Ceilometer is most often thought of as a way to get usage and metering information into a system for billing or usage show-back.  Many people don't realize it's potential as a way to identify "abusive" or "heavy-duty" users.

In this presentation, Overstock.com's Lead Cloud Systems Architect will walk you through simple and effective ways to use Ceilometer data to identify heavy users of CPU, disk I/O, and network during those critical times when usage is spiking and you need to go on a 'witch-hunt' for the culprit.

As part of this presentation, Mike will step through the simple Python code he uses to retrieve, sort, and make sense of this vital information as an operator of the Overstock Private Cloud.

videos.name: Using Ceilometer Data for Effective Witch-Hunting

schedule.title: Gluon: An Enabler for NFV
schedule.description:
We've used Gluon to help us create new interfaces for our NFV needs, and we explain why and how.

Gluon is a service that lets you use multiple network APIs simultaneously in the same cloud.  Gluon lets a developer create new APIs that deal with very different networking environments without making radical changes to core Neutron.

A coalition of service providers and network vendors, brought together via OPNFV, have been exploring possibilities using this new option, and we report on the approach.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Gluon: An Enabler for NFV

schedule.title: How to Develop for OpenStack API's
schedule.description:
Building a cloud orchestrator is not like building any other cloud application.  Not because it is more challenging, they’re all challenging...but because an orchestrator needs to expose the full range of functionality that the underlying cloud exposes.

If the orchestrator can't provide the full range of cloud services, such as how to manage versioning dependencies, how to do unit, integration and system tests - just to name a few, what good is it ultimately?

That is why integrating with the cloud SDK correctly, while taking into account important aspects around idem-potency, dealing with errors, and even dealing with specific cloud quirks, requires users to have access to the full range of API functions and parameters through the orchestration template.  In this talk we’ll describe the techniques we used to expose the full OpenStack SDK to Cloudify blueprints, some of the pitfalls encountered, and how we overcame them.

videos.name: How to Develop for OpenStack API's

schedule.title: These Aren't the Logs You're Looking For
schedule.description: The event logs are usually our best friends for determining whether a system or its component is experiencing problems. With going away from single node setups we have to say goodbye to finding issues with ease just by reading logs here and there. As the number of nodes increase, it becomes painful to track the status of your deployment. Is there anything that might help? Yes, central logging service. With this approach we can quickly get answers to “why” and “where” something went wrong, even when malfunctioning component is offline, and there is no way to get to its local storage. But deploying a central logging service might turn out to be a little hassle itself. Luckily, you can take advantage of Docker and Ansible in Kolla, enabling you to have a full centralized logging stack in a matter of seconds. During this presentation we will invite you to the Loggingland and compare different containerized approaches - Logstash and Heka, both paired with Elasticsearch and Kibana.

videos.name: These Aren't the Logs You're Looking For

schedule.title: Virtual Routers on Compute Nodes - an (Not So) Irrational Decision?
schedule.description: Learn the production pros and cons of operating Neutron legacy and HA routers on compute nodes in your production cloud. Not ready for DVR or third-party network overhauls? Virtual router network “hot spots” got you down?  Large virtual router failure domains keeping you up late at night?  Neutron reference architectures not providing a scalable routing solution?  If you answered yes to any of these questions then this talk is for you.

videos.name: Virtual Routers on Compute Nodes - an (Not So) Irrational Decision?

schedule.title: Ancestry.com in Production with OpenStack and Kubernetes
schedule.description:
In Tokyo, we shared Ancestry's OpenStack, Docker and Kubernetes Journey. We have learned even more in the latest release cycle, and hope to share deeper details in a few areas where we have had success:

  • Developers using a mix of Swift API and AWS S3 API in their applications storing on Swift
  • Adding a filesystem gateway in front of Swift for apps needing POSIX and and high performance
  • Experiences continuing down the path with Kubernetes and OpenStack @ Ancestry

videos.name: Ancestry.com in Production with OpenStack and Kubernetes

schedule.title: Ceilometer, Nova and Neutron – Working Together to Provide a Healthy Network for Your Cloud
schedule.description:
Today OpenStack is able to track the state of hypervisors hardware with nova compute running on each hypervisor node. With state of the hardware known, OpenStack can do a better job at finding out the Hypervisor that matches the resource needed to host a Virtual Machine.

Although Neutron agents collect some state data for the Network Nodes, Neutron has no knowledge of the state of the physical networking devices.

In this presentation, we will discuss the following ideas to leverage network health monitoring for your OpenStack workloads:

  • Nova to Neutron interaction for physical network details - we will discuss the APIs that allow operators to integrate the physical network information for use in workload placement
  • Using Ceilometer to collect physical network stats - we will discuss how health of physical network can be modeled to provide operational insight
  • Network aware Nova Scheduler - a Nova scheduler that considers the network conditions while selecting a hypervisor for the workload.

videos.name: Ceilometer, Nova and Neutron – Working Together to Provide a Healthy Network for Your Cloud

schedule.title: Persistent Storage for Containers Using Cinder
schedule.description: Everyone loves containers, but nobody wants to talk about the elephant in the room - how can you make storage persist when the whole point of containers is that they have short lifespans? In this presentation we'll discuss how to use the REX-Ray volume driver, backed by Cinder, to provide persistent, preemptable storage to Docker container servers hosted on OpenStack.

videos.name: Persistent Storage for Containers Using Cinder

schedule.title: Tutorial on Heat Template (Auto-scaling, Software Deployment)
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

While working on the heat project, came across many situations where users want to know more about

  • how to write heat template
  • What are diffrenent functoinalities could be achieved using heat
  • How nested template works
  • What is heat environment and how it helps the user.

So this presentation will help user to learn about all of these.

videos.name: Tutorial on Heat Template (Auto-scaling, Software Deployment)

schedule.title: Security Vulnerabilities in OpenStack Deployments
schedule.description: vBrownBag

schedule.title: Hitachi Data Systems Corporation - Hitachi Brings Resilience and Automation to OpenStack
schedule.description:
Join Hitachi to discover how we are leveraging open source technology and our legendary enterprise resilience to create innovative open cloud solutions. Learn about the ways we participate in the OpenStack community, including which projects and groups we are involved in and how we are using our software development and system implementation knowledge and experience to the benefit of the community.

Experience technology previews featuring Hitachi Automation Director enabling a software-defined infrastructure using built-in intelligence and Cinder to provision storage. See how we automate end-to-end provisioning for a clustered web application using multiple OpenStack software components to enable Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) and Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS).

videos.name: Hitachi Data Systems Corporation - Hitachi Brings Resilience and Automation to OpenStack

schedule.title: Managing Container Clusters in OpenStack Native Way
schedule.description:
On its journey to become an integration engine of cloud technologies, OpenStack has been actively incubating many technologies related to containers. However, containers are yet to be treated as first class citizens on OpenStack. In other words, it may not be sufficient to just bridge the existing OpenStack services to other container technologies.

In this talk, the presenters will share their visions and experiences on managing container clusters directly using OpenStack native services. The goal of the work is to explore the feasibility to treat containers as first class citizens in OpenStack rather than above OpenStack. A comprehensive support to containers will help ease the development, testing, deployment and management of containers considering that, for example, users have to work with Python, Go, Java, C, Scalar code in different projects.

videos.name: Managing Container Clusters in OpenStack Native Way

schedule.title: EMC - Enterprise Storage Management for Mixed Cloud Environments with CoprHD
schedule.description: For OpenStack users and developers, Swift, Manila and Cinder are enough to satisfy data availability and converged infrastructure needs. But consider the following scenarios: - You have an existing cloud or virtualization platform, and you want to add OpenStack to the mix (or vice versa). How do you utilize existing storage platforms shared between compute and orchestration services? - You have existing storage arrays serving data to a set of applications, with policy-based storage management. What is the most seamless way to connect to an OpenStack-based cloud with the least disruption? In both cases, it makes sense to utilize a software-defined storage controller that is able to direct storage traffic between storage infrastructure and orchestration platforms, including OpenStack. In this talk, we'll use the open source CoprHD platform as an example of how to connect OpenStack with enterprise storage.

videos.name: EMC - Enterprise Storage Management for Mixed Cloud Environments with CoprHD

schedule.title: NFV Orchestration - Project Landscape
schedule.description:
NFV Orchestration spans lots of components and organizations. This Birds of Feathers session will bring various interested parties in the OpenSource and Standards Organizations to come together to discuss and further OpenStack based solutions for NFV Orchestration. 

Some of the Organizations and OpenSource communities involved in the NFV Orchestration space that expect to attend this are:

OpenStack:

  1. Tacker (NFV Orchestrator / VNF Manager )
  2. Neutron (Service Function Chaining)
  3. Senlin (Cloud Clustering and AutoScaling)
  4. Tricircle (MultiSite OpenStack)

OPNFV:

  1. Parser Project (Template requirements)
  2. Service Function Chaining
  3. VNF Forwarding Graph
  4. MultiSite

Standards Organizations:

  1. ETSI NFV
  2. OASIS TOSCA (Data-Model standards)
  3. IETF NFVRG

schedule.title: Openstack-based Technologies R & D in Taiwan
schedule.description:
Part 1 - Software Defined Data Center and PCIe-Based Rack Scale Architecture, we will introduce two main subjects – applied research and development for software defined data center and rack scale architecture (RSA).  For the first subject, we will highlight the enhancement we did for IOD (ITRI OpenStack Distribution), which includes Peregrine (Neutron Plug-in), DISCO (Cinder plug-in), HaaS and Monitoring (PDCM). Our proposal of RSA is based on PCIe bus for intra-rack communication to reap the benefit of software defined server, resource (NIC, Storage, Memory) pooling, high density, real time and low latency.  This hyper-converged architecture has a natural adaptation for NFV, high end SDS and high performance computing. 

 OpenStack has emerged as a leading platform technology for building and deploying cloud computing platform and data center. At the same time, applying big data technology/analytics solutions to address business problems has caught every business executive’s attention.  Part II - OpenStack Based Big Data Analytics Platform and Applications, we will present our research and development work that incorporates OpenStack as a foundation layer for building a big data analytics (BDA) platform. Unlike traditional big data platform that uses HDFS for file and object storage and Ambori for monitoring and cluster management, our BDA platform (codename Bistro) uses OpenStack for file/object storage, cluster management among other things. In addition, we will share our experience in developing and deploying our big data analytics solutions with Bistro in a few real customer scenarios.

videos.name: Openstack-based Technologies R & D in Taiwan

schedule.title: Implementing vCPE with OpenStack and Software Defined Networks
schedule.description:
Service providers and the broader vendor community have made progress in virtualizing key vCPE network functions. Concurrently, there is a strong push to bring these functions to the cloud. This session will discuss how Openstack is enabling this transformation and the role played by technologies like SDN and NFV. It will also discuss the latest advances in the networking stack of the Linux kernel which further enable these network functions to run in a fully distributed architecture. Finally, it will tie all these concepts together proposing a model for implementing virtual CPE services.

 

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Implementing vCPE with OpenStack and Software Defined Networks

schedule.title: Nova: Performance VMs CI and technical debt
schedule.description:
There is a lot of interest in high performance VMs using PCI, NUMA, SR-IOV, FPGA/vGPU, CPU pinning, and hugepages but the test coverage is minimal in a lot of cases and upstream coordination seems difficult at times.

In this session we'll discuss the current state of the 3rd party CI testing for these various configurations, identify the gaps and how to close those, and who will own the work.

We'll also discuss technical debt that is blocking new feature adoption, or known issues that need to be fixed.

Finally, sub-team coordination will be discussed to improve the focus in this area.

References:

* The same SRIOV / NFV CI failures missed a regression, why?

Etherpad

Chair(s): Matt Riedemann (mriedem), Sylvain Bauza (bauzas)

schedule.title: Cinder: Mitaka Recap, Part 2
schedule.description:
A lot changed that developers need to be aware of. The plan is to have part presentation, part discussion to make sure everyone is aware of changes, knows what to look out for in reviews, and understands any new restrictions.

Topics:
Microversions for developing new functionality
scottda will lead this presentation
* What's implemented
* How it should be used
* Do's and Dont's
* Example of implementing it in one API

Conditional DB updates for developing new functionality and making changes to the API
geguileo will lead this presentation
* What's implemented
* Advanced functionality
- Using DB fields instead of reading the data and changing it
- Easily joining multiple tables
- etc.
* Things that cannot be done because one of supported SQL engines does not support it

Rolling upgrades for developing new functionality
geguileo and dulek will lead this presentation
*devref patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279186/ ). <-- This is what I was hopping for ;-)
* What's implemented and what not (post install migrations)
* Do's and dont's when creating new patches
- For example you cannot directly drop a field that is already in use, you need 1 release in between
- Renaming a field requires 3 releases, and it must be done in a specific way
- If a versioned object changes it needs to be careful with the obj_make_compatible
* Example of changes

Freezer Disaster Recovery

DR is a broad definition that goes from losing one node to an entire datacenter. There are various approaches to mitigate these events, from backup/restore to more advanced strategies.
Freezer goal has always been to be a DR solution and so far focusing on the backup approach, now we can look a bit further and implement something to achieve lower RTO/RPO’s.

This session will aim at brainstorming ideas to achieve this.
