schedule.title: SearchLight: API Callbacks are Bad - Improve the Notifications (Nova, Neutron, Ironic, etc.)
schedule.description:
Searchlight dramatically improves the user focused search capabilities and performance on behalf of various OpenStack cloud services. It accomplishes this by offloading user search queries from existing API servers and indexing their data into ElasticSearch.

Initial indexing is done on demand, but keeping the index up-to-date is dependent on notifications from the various services. Right now there are gaps in data and events from the various services.

In a number of places we're forced to hit service APIs in notification handlers because notifications don't contain all the information we'd like to index. We've justified this by asserting that the information we get from APIs is necessary to index, but this has backed us into a corner in some places (notably Nova). We need to decide whether this continues to be OK, or whether we put more emphasis on improving notifications and/or accepting some data cannot be indexed.

We'd ideally like to get contributors from other service teams (Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Glance, Ironic, Magnum, others) into this room to help understand the Searchlight needs and help us to understand the impact of improving notification vs API callbacks. This session will include providing a very quick demo of searchlight and a brief architectural review for anybody that would like to better understand searchlight and to help guide the discussion.

* Etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/searchlight-newton-summit-notifications
* Wiki: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Searchlight

Secondary Topic:
API Data Normalization in the index (if not discussed here, will flow into follow-on session)
* Etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/searchlight-newton-summit-api-normalization

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
schedule.description:
Ceilometer splitting, the next steps.

Discussion about what is going to be split next in Ceilometer, like we did with alarming and Aodh.

schedule.title: Turn up the Heat with LBaaS v2
schedule.description:
This presentation will start by introducing basic concepts in using Heat with Load Balancer As A Service (LBaaS) v2. Have you been wondering whether to use LBaaS v1 or LBaaS v2 especially if you are using Heat? This session will help you get a good understanding of the advantages of LBaaS v2 and some of the reasons on why you should not mix and match LBaaS v1 and LBaaS v2.

We will cover fundamental differences between LBaaS v1 and LBaaS v2 from a Heat perspective; discuss the Heat resource hierarchy and dive into the depths of the resource properties and attributes.

Want to see it in action? We will make the learning practical by showing Heat template examples for LBaaS v2.

videos.name: Turn up the Heat with LBaaS v2

schedule.title: Installing, Configuring, and Managing a 300+ OpenStack Node Network In Under An Hour
schedule.description: Deploying and managing a large OpenStack deployment can be daunting, but much easier when you use standard DevOps automation tools, a Linux-based network, and commodity servers and switches. This session details the design and implementation of an L3 network underlay, routing to the host, and a hardware VXLAN gateway used with an enterprise OpenStack distribution on 300+ OpenStack compute nodes.

videos.name: Installing, Configuring, and Managing a 300+ OpenStack Node Network In Under An Hour

schedule.title: I18n Workshop: Translation Processes and Tools
schedule.description:
I18n team is responsible to make OpenStack accessible to people of all language backgrounds. We translate OpenStack dashboard and OpenStack documents into different languages. We have processes to manage translation related activities, e.g. glossary, translation memory, review, translation check and etc. We have tools to support these processes, e.g. use Zanata and automation jobs.

In this session, we want to collect feedback from translators and evaluate the inconveniences of current translation tools and translation processes. We will have translators and tool developers together and discuss about how to improve in the future.

The workshop agenda and discussions will be tracked here: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/austin-i18n-workshop.

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: Write a File, Read as an Object
schedule.description: This session tells about a solution to "objectize" files ingested via file interface like NFS/SMB to make them visible in Swift container listing so they can be accessed via object interface (Openstack Swift). The session begins with a short overview of SwiftOnFile, which is needed to understand the data placement mechanism for unified file and object access. We will then explain the "objectization" process that does synchronization between file metadata and object metadata that ensures accurate container and account listing. This honors Swift semantics of “eventual consistency” where file data gets reflected in object interface eventually. We will also talk about how the file protocol's authorization semantics are honored by preserving the Access Control Lists set on files and directories from file interface.

videos.name: Write a File, Read as an Object

schedule.title: Policy Canvas: Draw Your Policies for OpenStack Services
schedule.description: We introduce a Policy Canvas which is a highly user-friendly and simple front-end interface to manage policies like drawing diagrams on whiteboard or note. Most administrators and operators draw their policies first in hand and translate them to specific policy languages or commands manually. It is error-prone and requires much time and effort. Our system provides a unified and simple graph drawing tool for specifying policies for multiple OpenStack services. It can automatically translate the graph model to relevant OpenStack services using APIs and commands. In addition, some of the policies can be given by multiple stakeholders such as tenant, cloud operator, system administrator, or application developers. Our system can detect/resolve conflicts as much as possible. In this session, we introduce our Policy Canvas running on Horizon and demonstrate how to create multiple network policies and automatically deploy them to the OpenStack via Congress and Neutron.

videos.name: Policy Canvas: Draw Your Policies for OpenStack Services

schedule.title: Speeding up Developer Productivity with OpenStack and Open Source Tools
schedule.description:
OpenStack’s orchestration service and APIs enable developers to easily deploy application infrastructure themselves…but what if developers want to use the popular open source tools with which they're already familiar?

This talk covers how developers can use tools from HashiCorp (Vagrant, Terraform, Packer), Docker, Ansible, Puppet, and others to quickly provision workloads on OpenStack clouds. The presenters will share practical examples that attendees can follow along with at the talk and/or take back home to try in their own labs.

videos.name: Speeding up Developer Productivity with OpenStack and Open Source Tools

schedule.title: Neutron Quality of Service, New Features And Future Roadmap.
schedule.description:
Starting at Liberty, the Neutron team introduced the Quality of Service framework, the initial stone to provide quality of service settings on the Neutron networking API.

The initial implementation only supported VM-egress bandwidth policing, addressing the chatty neighbour use case, and letting CSPs provide different levels of network service if they wanted.

In Mitaka, two new features are being introduced:

  • DSCP rules, to mark and prioritize traffic at L3 level.
  • Role based access control for QoS policies, allowing a finer grade of sharing for QoS policies, the administrator would be able to share specific policies with specific tenants, oposed to the previous (share/no share to all the tenants).

Also support has been extended from the OVS and SRIOV agents, to Linux Bridge, while OVN is also considering to implement QoS support too.

videos.name: Neutron Quality of Service, New Features And Future Roadmap.

schedule.title: Integration of Neutron, Nova and Designate: How to Use It and How to Configure It
schedule.description: This presentations will be a hands on demonstration on how to use and configure the integration between Neutron, Nova and Designate.The approach will be highly practical. Attendees will be provided with a VM with DevStack, where they will be able to follow the presentation.

videos.name: Integration of Neutron, Nova and Designate: How to Use It and How to Configure It

schedule.title: Fostering Full Equality, Organized by the Women of OpenStack
schedule.description:
Following up on the themes related to gender equality presented at the previous Summit talks sponsored by The Women of OpenStack working group, this session will focus on our vision of a world where the OpenStack community is truly and completely blind to meaningless differences in gender, color, creed and culture. What will this new world look like? How will it differ from the current one?

A panel of people from all walks of life will explore what that future is and what we can do as a community as a whole to achieve it.

videos.name: Fostering Full Equality, Organized by the Women of OpenStack

schedule.title: Install and Configure OpenStack Octavia
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

In this interactive workshop, members of the Octavia team will walk attendees through the installation and configuration of Octavia, the Open Stack LoadBalancer, on a virtual machine. Attendees will leave with an understanding of the various components of Octavia, how to configure and tune the controller and the amphora.

Attendees will learn: 

  • Octavia Architecture 101
  • How to Install and Configure Octavia
  • How to enable Active-Standby
  • How to perform day to day Octavia operations tasks
  • End user usage of the API, CLI, Horizon UI
  • Tips and Tricks for using Octavia
  • Contributing to Octavia 101

videos.name: Install and Configure OpenStack Octavia

schedule.title: Deploying Application Infrastructure on OpenStack
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

This hands-on workshop aims to introduce a set of tools for automating infrastructure deployment, network troubleshooting, and traffic monitoring on OpenStack clouds. Members of the audience will be provided access to their own dedicated OpenStack environment. We begin by introducing Heat Orchestration Templates, and provisioning a 3-tier app in the OpenStack cloud. This exercise highlights automated network configuration of both virtual and physical network workloads. We then gain hands-on experience with advanced network troubleshooting techniques. The speaker will then guide the audience in the process of deploying monitoring infrastructure. Attendees will be provided free access to online OpenStack labs for an additional three months.

videos.name: Deploying Application Infrastructure on OpenStack

schedule.description:
We've been talking about integrating support for Glance's v2 API in Nova since Kilo. Some progress was made in Mitaka but the overall picture is not yet clear on the integration. We need to get the Nova and Glance team in a room and hash out the plan so we can finally get this done in Newton.

Notes:

* Etherpad with more details on v2 integration
* Mailing list thread on basic things needed to start the integration

Issues:

* The spec is focused mostly on the tail end of the changes (steps 10-20) rather than the initial cleanup steps which are laid out in Sean's ML thread.
* What can we push into python-glanceclient so it's not living in Nova's image API code?
* CI testing for Nova + Glance v2 in the gate.
* CI testing for XenAPI with Glance v2?

Session etherpad

Chairs: Sean Dague (sdague), Nikhil Komawar (nikhil), Mike Fedosin (mfedosin), Matt Riedemann (mriedem)

schedule.title: Rally: Mission and Goals
schedule.description: If you are new in Rally community and you would like to get more information about it, understand the mission and goals of the project, as well get involved in community processes this session is for exactly for you.

schedule.title: Zaqar: Improved notification format
schedule.description: Not just send messages to subscribers, but special "notifications". They contain project id, queue name, multiple messages and their ids. All in a single body. I'm thinking if it's possible getting the message id before sending messages to subscribers. Here's one of the possible solutions: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/276968/. Personally, I would like to see more details  Need more details before voting Like aliyun's MNS, we can support two types of notificaiton content format, one is simple format, only contain the messages and meesage ids, other is whole format, that contain project id, queue name, messages and ids, when subscriber creates the subscription, they can specify the NotifyContentFormat as SIMPLE or WHOLE.

schedule.title: Watcher, a Resource Manager for OpenStack: Plans for the N-release and Beyond
schedule.description: Watcher is an open source software package which provides a flexible and scalable resource optimization service for multi-tenant OpenStack-based clouds. Watcher provides a complete optimization loop—including everything from a metrics receiver, optimization processor andan action plan applier. This provides a robust framework to realize a wide range of cloud optimization goals, including the reduction of data center operating costs, increased system performance via intelligent virtual machine migration,increased energy efficiency, etc. The overall goal is that OpenStack-based clouds equipped with Watcher will decrease their Total Cost of Ownership by way of more efficient use of their infrastructure through targeted optimizations and close-loop automation. In this talk we will go over the state of Watcher as it is today, its architecture, the team’s accomplishments for the Mitaka release and our plans for the N-release and beyond.

videos.name: Watcher, a Resource Manager for OpenStack: Plans for the N-release and Beyond

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
schedule.description:
Let's talk about documentation.

Currently, the doc is split and managed differently in all telemetry projects. Let's try to bring all of that to a better state and unify a bit our policy.

schedule.title: FILE This: Swift API, Then S3 API, And Now POSIX Access to OpenStack Swift
schedule.description:
OpenStack developers have had all they need in the Swift API to build new applications and store unstructured data in Swift. But what about classic apps that are not yet refactored? And maybe there are requirements to read from or move data between Swift and NAS storage.

SwiftStack has middleware for Amazon S3 API support, and is working on building support for POSIX interfaces directly into Swift. The Swift PTL, as well as the author of the O'Reilly publication "OpenStack Swift", lead this session and share the exciting developments that will broaden Swift's ability to support more application workloads and store more data.

videos.name: FILE This: Swift API, Then S3 API, And Now POSIX Access to OpenStack Swift

schedule.title: Networking-Calico, a Routing-Based Implementation of IP-Only Connectivity Between VMs - What, Why, How and the Future
schedule.description: networking-calico is a Neutron driver that provides IP-only connectivity between VMs based on standard IP routing and iptables. It is a new project in the Neutron stadium since last August, but has not yet been fully introduced to the Neutron developer community. This talk will explain what the networking-calico project is, why it is interesting for some OpenStack deployments, and how it works so far. I will also talk about what more is needed for networking-calico to be a first class member of the Neutron project and community, both technically and procedurally; and finish with musing on the relationship between Neutron’s backends and its API, and why it makes sense – at least transiently – to have multiple backends implementing the same API.

videos.name: Networking-Calico, a Routing-Based Implementation of IP-Only Connectivity Between VMs - What, Why, How and the Future

schedule.title: A PaaS for Continuous Delivery of Cloud Native Apps. (minus Kubernetes and Mesos)
schedule.description:
Although there are variety of PaaS, enterprises require finer granularity and adaptability of development and deployment methodologies to existing practices and tools. Mesos, Kubernetes, etc. although popular still is IaaS albeit at a higher level of abstraction.

We'll take a fairly minimal openstack install and build a platform on top of it using standard open source tooling like Docker, Deis, etc. We will then take you through the application lifecycle of a cloud native application showing you how to use CI/CD on top of that platform and all you have to care about is your development workflow against github.

We will provide an environment with some tools integrated, requiring attendees to work on simple exercises and complement the platform with other tools and to follow the methodologies of continuous deployment. Once this is done, it can greatly simplify the development and deployment of applications and greatly reduce the time it takes to take a feature from idea to product.

videos.name: A PaaS for Continuous Delivery of Cloud Native Apps. (minus Kubernetes and Mesos)

schedule.title: Striving for a High-Performance NFV Grid on OpenStack. Why You, and Every OpenStack Community Member Should Be Excited About It.
schedule.description:
The idea of OpenStack as a vehicle to build, and operate NFV platforms is going mainstream. As it does, it continues to provide impetus to OpenStack ecosystem on numerous fronts. It is truly exciting to imagine the possibilities that open up as developers, users, architects, and operators push the performance, quality, and innovation in the ecosystem.

AT&T and other large service providers are driving efforts to make it possible to push 100 gigabit line rate on software switches, NUMA support among other things.

This session explores how the community as a whole benefits from rising NFV adoption. We then deep dive into DPI, and MEC as NFV use cases.

  • Technical overview of NFV related developments, and AT&T's innovations in OpenStack around this.
  • NUMA, SR-IOV, DPDK, RDMA - Why do they matter?
  • Use-case: Pushing the performance limit to achieve DPI capability on OpenStack.
  • Keys attributes of a high performing packet processing path.
  • The MEC (Mobile Edge Computing) use case.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Striving for a High-Performance NFV Grid on OpenStack. Why You, and Every OpenStack Community Member Should Be Excited About It.

schedule.title: Do Containers Become First Class Citizens in the Data Center? - Moderated by Cliff Grossner, Ph.D. IHS
schedule.description: Containers quickly rose in popularity among developers with standardization driving portability, and have led to new micro-segmented software architectures providing agility for solving large distributed computing tasks, such as big data analytics or motion picture rendering. What is the proper role for containers in the data center today? Do they become peers with virtual machines and bare metal computing and managed by the same platforms? Will they be deployed on all devices, such as servers, network adapter cards, network devices, etc? This panel will discuss the role containers will assume in the data center and how this important technology integrates with existing infrastructure in 2016 and beyond.

videos.name: Do Containers Become First Class Citizens in the Data Center? - Moderated by Cliff Grossner, Ph.D. IHS

schedule.title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About OpenStack at Scale
schedule.description: A de facto guide to the scaling models, capabilities and limits of all OpenStack components. I will cover all core projects, their components and the limitations of each. In general, OpenStack scaling models fit into three categories: vertically scalable, horizontally scalable or sharded, which is a special case of horizontally scalable. Along with this overview I will take the opportunity to review structural details, future plans and past mistakes. Q&A should be a large part of this presentation. Please attend with lots of questions to ask.

videos.name: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About OpenStack at Scale

schedule.title: Tanks in The Clouds
schedule.description:
G-Core, a Luxembourg-based global IT solutions provider, has moved its G-Core Innovations IT infrastructure (DCs) to OpenStack from VMware. With Wargaming as a key client, this solution will support its military MMOs, with a multimillion user base, including World of Tanks and World of Warships.

When one says these games are popular, they mean that more than 1 million users are playing simultaneously (http://bit.ly/1TA5Ggw). To make that possible, G-Core provides Wargaming with more than 20 data centers (consisting of thousands of servers) all over the world.

G-Core has a huge and complex infrastructure to provide stable solutions, capable of enduring high loads. Using this experience, G-Core is able to find solutions and share expertise with other companies that require a competitive and robust service. This case study shows the huge, infrastructural move from VMware to OpenStack and describes the basic architectural solutions of the project.

videos.name: Tanks in The Clouds

schedule.title: A Pioneer's Vision of Networking
schedule.description: In this session, Guido Appenzeller---a founding member and pioneer of the revolution to virtualize the network---will share his vision on how networking is moving up the stack, and will discuss the role of OpenStack in this new age. The growing importance of public clouds, mobile devices, and multi-cloud strategies means that networking today is not about hardware but instead is about logical endpoints. The hard part is managing connectivity, compliance, and security in a scalable, policy-driven fashion. Come listen to this pioneer's vision of the future of networking and how that will impact OpenStack.

videos.name: A Pioneer's Vision of Networking

schedule.title: Newcomers Need You, How to Be A Good Mentor
schedule.description: You still remember the first time you've heard the word OpenStack, the efforts you had to make to wrap your head around it and to get your first patch merged. Now you know enough to be able to teach other people and put them up to speed. You would like to be a mentor but you are not sure about how time consuming it might be, you still have doubts and questions. In this session we will try to answer them. We will give advices based on our experience mentoring in the Outreachy and Google Summer of Code programs, suggest some strategies and list the most common mistakes a new mentor does.

videos.name: Newcomers Need You, How to Be A Good Mentor

schedule.title: DPDK, Collectd & Ceilometer: The Missing Link Between My Telco Cloud and The NFV Infrastructure
schedule.description:
Collectd exposes statistics that facilitate more resilient and performant telco/NFV clouds.

It is vital to monitor systems for malfunctions that could lead to users’ application service disruption and promptly react to these fault events to facilitate improving overall system performance.

By providing Ceilometer with system statistics from collectd, there is more data available, which can be used for monitoring, performance analysis, fault detection, etc. using OPNFV Doctor-prescribed enhancements to OpenStack, action can then be taken to negate the effects of any faults in the deployment.

Gaps have been identified and work to improve OpenStack to enable a more fault tolerant cloud environment is well underway. A key part of this work includes expanding the amount of data available about the system (e.g. DPDK statistics), and improving alarming functionality in OpenStack Aodh.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: DPDK, Collectd & Ceilometer: The Missing Link Between My Telco Cloud and The NFV Infrastructure

- Lightweight HA architecture (templates, upgrades, etc.)

- How do we get from composable services to fully composable roles?

schedule.title: Zaqar: Work session
schedule.description:
Title: Deprecate pool group

Description: Now the relationship between pool, pool group and flavor is pool(N)<--> poolgroup(1) <--> flavor(1), so we don't really need the pool group. Because for now, Zaqar only supports two types of message storage, redis and mongodb. That said, there are only two flavors at most, one for redis and one for mongodb. Though technically, operator may create more than one pool group for one storage type, for example, user(cloud provider) has 10 mongo instances, they may put 4 instances into mongo-group-1 and put another 6 into mongo-group-2. But unfortunately, in Zaqar's flavor, only ONE pool gruop can be set. And I would admit, if we remove pool group and let pool map to flaovr directly, it's a little bit weird(though i don't know why it's weird :)

schedule.title: Magnum: Unified Container Abstraction for Different COEs
schedule.description: Magnum aims to provide container-as-a-service for OpenStack. Currently, Magnum supports provisioning various Container Orchestration Engines (COEs), including Kubernetes, Docker Swarm and Apache Mesos. Different COEs have its own APIs and unique functionalities, and workloads are not portable between COEs. This session will discuss if it makes sense to introduce a common abstraction layer that hides the heterogeneity of different COEs. In particular, we will focus on a Container abstraction that unifies the lifecycle management of containers across all COEs.

The unified entry point exists and the old utilities have been migrated to it.
However, key functionality like the run command are still missing.
This session will be to discuss what functionality is missing and how to implement it.

Related link: https://github.com/openstack/qa-specs/blob/master/specs/tempest/tempest-cli-improvements.rst

schedule.title: OpenStack and the IoT: Where We Stand, Where We're Going, What We Need to Get There
schedule.description: The Internet of Things (IoT), with its multitude of devices making calls to applications, is a perfect use case for the scalable, adaptable environment that is OpenStack. But that doesn't mean that we're ready -- not by a long shot. In this panel, a group of application developers, network engineers, and security experts will look at what OpenStack can already accomplish, and what needs to happen in order for OpenStack to fulfill its potential.

videos.name: OpenStack and the IoT: Where We Stand, Where We're Going, What We Need to Get There

We'll also demonstrate our v2 API, the Horizon plugin and the OSC CLI plugin allowing users to easily use the App Catalog.

If you have any interest in building the Application Ecosystem within OpenStack please be sure to join us so we can be certain we're all heading in the right direction together!

schedule.title: Rolling Your Own Kubernetes Clusters on OpenStack with Ansible and Terraform
schedule.description: As interest grows around the container ecosystem, enterprises are looking to explore orchestration tools such as Kubernetes. This talk will give a tour of the community resources available for deploying Kubernetes clusters on any group of servers, as well as how to leverage tools like Terraform to automate the creation of necessary infrastructure. We will end with a demo of a full end-to-end deployment of a small cluster.

videos.name: Rolling Your Own Kubernetes Clusters on OpenStack with Ansible and Terraform

schedule.title: Achieve Low Latency NFV with Openstack
schedule.description:
Since K release, a lot of advanced features have been added to openstack, like CPU pinning, NUMA Topology Awareness, Huge Page support etc. In the M release, the real time support is also added to Nova. With all these features, openstack can provide best performance optimization for high performance VM, with exclusively assigned resource and best hardware compute capability utilization.

In this session, we will show how the advanced openstack features help on an important usage scenario, the low latency and high throughput NFV. It has been challenging to achieve low latency and high performance VNF on cloud environment. Packet jitter comes from various factors, like virtualization overhead, not optimized compute node environment, not optimized network topology overhead etc.  KVM4NFV project on OPNFV provides low level support for low latency NFV usage, but only with the advanced openstack features, it’s possible to achieve the purpose on OPNFV.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Achieve Low Latency NFV with Openstack

schedule.title: Build It and They Will Come (Easier Said Than Done!)
schedule.description: OpenStack Cloud Computing is much more than technology. It’s a community. And our community wasn’t built by accident! Building and growing this amazing community has been a result of the very deliberate efforts of some extremely dedicated people, as well as crucial community tools like GitHub, IRC, Stack Overflow, Google Hangout, and Twitter. Great OpenStack meetups are powerful. They foster a collaborative, inclusive environment, focused on important issues to the developers and users who make OpenStack tick. Across the world, individual leaders are finding a remedy for the detachment that sometimes plagues remote workers by hosting sanctioned OpenStack Meetups to share and exchange information. Come meet 4 of the top OpenStack Community Managers and OpenStack meetup organizers and hear how they have managed to grow and nurture this vibrant community. Learn best practices and tips and tricks for starting meetups in your area, and retaining your devoted followers.

videos.name: Build It and They Will Come (Easier Said Than Done!)

schedule.title: Practical OVN: Architecture, Deployment, and Scale of OpenStack Networking
schedule.description: OVN is a network virtualization project that brings virtual networking to the Open vSwitch user community and is the latest iteration of Open vSwitch integration for OpenStack.  It is an open source project being developed by the core OVS development community, which includes large-scale network operators.  In this talk, we will cover the state of OVN with a focus on deployment. Topics include using overlay and local network configurations, implementing security policies, gateway placement, current scale limits, and future feature plans

videos.name: Practical OVN: Architecture, Deployment, and Scale of OpenStack Networking

schedule.title: Open Source Networking Development: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
schedule.description: Open Source Networking reached critical mass in 2015, with an onslaught of new projects combining with many existing projects to create a vibrant ecosystem. Being productive in many of these projects can require a blend of unique skills. Each project can do things a little differently and having a frustration free experience across the board can be a challenge. The good news is that in this talk you will learn how to effectively work across many of these Open Source networking projects and how to deal with failure as well as success. We'll compare how these projects take on new work, how they consume this new work, and ultimately how they fold it into their projects. We will take you on a light-hearted ride through contribution and collaboration strategies that can lead to success, as well as strategies that can lead to a painful crash and burn.

videos.name: Open Source Networking Development: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

schedule.title: Understanding ML2 Port Binding
schedule.description:
The Modular Layer 2 (ML2) core plugin underlies the majority of Neutron deployments, including those using the reference Open vSwitch and Linux Bridge L2 agents, as well as various vendor-specific solutions. If you've deployed, operated, or even just used an ML2-based setup, you may have encountered "binding failed" errors, and wondered what could have gone wrong. Or you may just want to better understand how ML2 works and what it can do.

The focus of this session, ML2's "port binding", is the process by which the ML2 plugin selects the mechanism driver(s) and network segment(s) to be utilized for a specific Neutron port. Port binding must succeed before a port will provide the requested connectivity. Its outcome configures the datapath and determines the details needed by Nova or other services to connect to the desired Neutron network. Port binding enables ML2 to support heterogeneous environments. Understanding how it works is critical to getting the most out of ML2.

videos.name: Understanding ML2 Port Binding

schedule.title: Embracing OpenStack - The Verizon User Story Journey
schedule.description:
The road to embrace OpenStack at Verizon offers lessons in the need for companies to manage the business, cultural and technical changes that come with any large systems implementation, while overcoming the unique challenges of incorporating OpenStack into an organization unfamiliar with the open source model.   

As a telecommunications giant, Verizon has a large and complex heterogeneous portfolio of applications and systems to support its global businesses and products. Verizon looked to use OpenStack because it has the capability for the hyper scale and flexibility to support the company's many interconnected requirements. However, such a fundamental change to the company's systems and processes is not going to happen overnight.

During this session we will share both the successes and lessons learned in implementing OpenStack into the Verizon environment.

videos.name: Embracing OpenStack - The Verizon User Story Journey

schedule.title: Dive into Nova Scheduler Performance - Where Is the Bottleneck?
schedule.description: There are always rumors around nova scheduler. Like "Scheduler can handle at most 1k nodes without problems" or "I don't believe scheduler can handle so much requests using only one tiny process". Some would prefer to launch couples of scheduler instances to multiply the schedule throughput, but still others might worry about race conditions and decision conflicts that could outweigh the benefits. Cloud users are interested in the deployment strategies to maximize the schedule performance, and developers are curious about the mystery of race condition and its performance impact. Guesses and speculations are everywhere without evidences. So let's do some experiments and let data do the talk!

videos.name: Dive into Nova Scheduler Performance - Where Is the Bottleneck?

schedule.title: Infrastructure as Code in OpenStack with Ansible - Advanced Neutron Use Cases
schedule.description:
This session will explore the step by step approach to deploy 4 popular use cases configuring advanced Neutron

1) Deploy a Load Balanced 2 tier infrastructure (Using Oracle and Tomcat) that leverages LBaaS v2.  How to perform proactive autoscaling by code - and bypassing the LBaaS v2 lack of integration with Heat / Ceilometer.

2) FWaaS use case to block by code certain ports in our two tier infrastructure while allowing your end users to still reach the core services.

3) Configure a VPNaaS across two separate OpenStack clouds.

In this use case our web services are running in one OpenStack cloud (could be a public cloud) while our database services are running safely on premise in a separate private cloud. VPNaaS will allow the comminication between Tomcat in our "public" cloud and Oracle in our "private" cloud.  This is transparent to the end user.

4) Baremetal provisioning with Ansible playbooks:  A quick demo to showcase the configuration management capabilities of Ansible on Baremetal.

videos.name: Infrastructure as Code in OpenStack with Ansible - Advanced Neutron Use Cases

schedule.title: Tap-As-A-Service:  What You Need to Know Now
schedule.description:
Tap-as-a-Service is a relatively new OpenStack project that was designed to provide tenants and service providers a means of monitoring the traffic flowing in their Neutron provisioned virtual networks. A lot of work has been carried out in the last two cycles, with multiple developers from around the world now contributing to the cause.

This presentation offers a review of all the progress made to date. We will discuss the primary motivations for monitoring network activity, explore the major challenges one can expect to encounter when attempting to monitor network traffic in a cloud environment and describe the need for a platform oriented solution. Next, an overview of the TaaS architecture and API will be presented, along with an update on current development activities and some of the planned enhancements for the future. We will also demonstrate traffic visibility solutions for a representative set of use cases covering network trouble-shooting, security and analytics.

videos.name: Tap-As-A-Service:  What You Need to Know Now

schedule.title: You Can Build Your OpenStack and Consume it Too
schedule.description: The power of the community is what makes open source initiatives extremely transformational—like OpenStack. On the other hand, enterprise users who are looking at adopting this solution need to go through a steep learning curve and deep transformation of their internal team structure. The power of OpenStack is actually greatly amplified by the ecosystem of vendors around it that look at important aspects like support and hardening as well as augmentation of specific aspects (e.g. scalability and performance) that are needed in production environments bringing the most value to users. Join Rackspace and PLUMgrid product specialists to learn how we jointly enable our Private Cloud enterprise users to consume OpenStack and Software Defined Networks (SDN) as ONE solution that brings comprehensive security, scalability and performance and a rich set of operational tools.

videos.name: You Can Build Your OpenStack and Consume it Too

schedule.description: Solum is a PaaS for OpenStack which allows deploying of applications starting from their source code, optionally running unit tests. We will present Solum's architecture, features, and give a demo.

schedule.title: Barbican: Supporting Key Management Tiers of Service
schedule.description:
There are several features that now incorporate encryption. Key management is crucial to the success of those features. The current solution for key management is to use asingle key manager for an OpenStack deployment, and every project will use the samekey manager.

This proposal will discuss how to support a key manager on a per project basis. This feature will allow cloud customers to choose amongst several key managers to choosethe one that best fits their needs. This will allow customers with highly sensitive data to choose a key manager that meets security requirements such as FIPS 140-2 whilecustomers with less senstive data can choose a basic software only implementation.

Blueprint: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/263972/

schedule.title: Developing Cloud Apps: HOT, TOSCA and MuranoPL
schedule.description:
Learn which app definition language is right for you and your cloud apps! App definition languages describe application requirements in abstract ways, enabling deployment on diverse infrastructure. What language choices are available for OpenStack? TOSCA, HOT and MuranoPL are three popular examples: the first an open standard, the latter two used by Heat and Murano, respectively.

How do they compare? Attendees at this session will get a deep dive into these three Domain-Specific Languages (DSLs) and learn:

  • What problem(s) each DSL is engineered to solve - conceptual distinctions among DSLs
  • What features each DSL supports
  • Comparative maturity, advantages and disadvantages of each DSL
  • Questions to ask before choosing a DSL for your project

They’ll leave with broad understanding of available DSL choices, intentions, features, limitations and constraints, and enough information to begin hands-on evaluation and selection.

videos.name: Developing Cloud Apps: HOT, TOSCA and MuranoPL

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
schedule.description: Let's talk about Vitrage and how we can help each others. The project is using Aodh heavily, so there are some things to discuss here.

schedule.title: Hands-On: Orchestrating Docker Containers with Heat
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

Roll up your sleeves & build Docker-based web services through the OpenStack Orchestration framework.  Docker provides a quick and consistent way to containerize your applications, making them perfect for deploying on a cloud platform.  OpenStack provides an orchestration framework, the Heat project, to allow end-users to quickly and easily deploy complex services in a consistent, scalable manner.  By combining the two, you now have a powerful tool to help you conquer the world.  These frameworks can be intimidating, however, and many users stay away because they're uncomfortable being responsible for instigating such a severe change in the way their company deploys.  In this session, we will introduce the basic concepts of OpenStack Orchestration and Docker, and provide hands-on experience to help demystify the process and get to that comfort level.  **Note** Attendees will need their own laptop to connect to our local OpenStack instance and fully participate in the lab.

videos.name: Hands-On: Orchestrating Docker Containers with Heat

schedule.title: Headless NFVi for PoP, CO or MSC/MSO
schedule.description:
The talk will discuss the challenges and mitigations centered around deployment and managing headless Network Function Virtualization infrastructure (NFVi) in PoP (Point of Presence), CO (Central Office), or a MSC/MSO (Mobile Switching Centre/Office):

1. Limiting data transfers to a minimum between control plane and computes across WAN/MAN.

2. Localizing resources to microDC like External Network and Block Storage access

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Headless NFVi for PoP, CO or MSC/MSO

schedule.title: Dynamic Routing of Networks in the Cloud
schedule.description: Among the commonly overlooked issues encountered when deploying Neutron is how to route traffic to and from tenant networks.  Many deployments are constrained such that statically routing tenant networks is sufficient. However, when tenants start using IPv6 and the scale of a deployment grows dynamic routing of tenant prefixes may become preferable to statically routing tenant prefixes.  In this session we will discuss how to use features added to Neutron over the last few cycles such as subnet pools, address scopes, and course Neutron BGP announcement to begin using dynamic routing in conjunction with a Neutron deployment.

videos.name: Dynamic Routing of Networks in the Cloud

schedule.title: Developing, Deploying, and Consuming L4-7 Network Services in an OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

The OpenStack infrastructure services for compute, networking, and storage have matured and are seeing increased adoption in production environments. In this tutorial session we will show you how to combine these fundamental services with other ancillary services around image management, security, monitoring, policy-based orchestration to build, deploy and consume rich networking services in your OpenStack Cloud.

This tutorial session is aimed at developers, operators, and users alike. A working environment will be provided to the attendees for experimentation. If you are a developer or vendor, you will learn how to leverage existing OpenStack constructs to expose your service offering. If you are an operator, you will learn how to configure, deploy and expose these service offerings in a few simple steps. If you are a user, you will learn how to consume single services, or compose a chain of services, and incorporate them in your application topology.

videos.name: Developing, Deploying, and Consuming L4-7 Network Services in an OpenStack Cloud

schedule.title: Magnum: Work session
schedule.description:
This session will discuss how to monitor bays and the containers running on the bays. The following areas will be explored:
* Monitor the health and resource utilization of bays.
* Monitor the containers running on each bay.
* Explore the integration of prevailing monitoring solution, such as cadvisor and Heapster.
* Explore a direction to emit notification/metrics to Ceilometer https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/magnum-ceilometer-integration .

schedule.title: Swift: Work session
schedule.description:
Working session 3: Looking to the future

Topics to cover include:

cluster full / improving rebalance time
hummingbird: where do we go?
hummingbird: how does it work?
reconstructor / ssync improvements
scaling swift for the future

schedule.title: TripleO: Work session
schedule.description:
Reducing the CI pain
- Status of CI - how can we improve capacity/performance issues, discussion on the infra vs third-party model, how to encourage third-party e.g vendors to add coverage
- OpenStack Virtual Baremetal now supports network-isolation and works without any host-cloud patches - lets discuss how we might use it in more places (dev environments via tripleo-quickstart, CI using standard nodepool devstack images)
- Are there ways we can reduce the maintenance burden, e.g more reuse between upstream/RDO CI (in terms of resources and CI implementation) - currently we're burning a ton of developer time keeping our CI running.
- Status of the things we've added to CI recently (net-iso, upgrades, ipv6, pingtest) - (how) can we continue to improve coverage (e.g tempest which is a constant RFE) within the constraints we have ref compute resources and walltime?

schedule.title: Tacker: Work session
schedule.description:
Technical Debt / Refactoring (lead: sripriya) - 40mins

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tacker-newton-refactoring

schedule.title: Rally: Work session
schedule.description:
Discuss features:

- Support of non OpenStack testing/benchmarking

-- Generalization of Rally Deployment structure (availability to store credentials of different)

-- Generalization of Rally Task (validation mechanism, types, cleaning up engine, ...)

-- Generalization of Rally Verify (support for basically any kind of functional testing frameworks based on unittest)


- New Task format

- Rally Task hooks

schedule.title: Nova: Priorities and schedule for Newton
schedule.description:
Wrap up the week with setting the priorities for the release and what the schedule is going to be (spec freeze, non-priority feature freeze, feature freeze, etc).

Etherpad

Newton release schedule

Chair: Matt Riedemann (mriedem)

schedule.title: Kuryr: Work session
schedule.description: Kuryr Integration with Mesos and Storage (moderator: fawadkhaliq, gsagie, apuimedo)

schedule.title: Neutron: Development track: completing the Mitaka backlog
schedule.description:
This session will cover all the specs which slipped Mitaka, and we'll quickly walk through the ones which need priority for Newton. We'll also try to evaluate if some of these need to be moved out of Newton due to no longer being in scope.

Session chair: armax

Etherpad

schedule.title: Solum: Work session
schedule.description:
Work sessions are for Solum contributors to discuss implementation details and making quick progress over specific issues, in a small work group environment.

Possible items that we will cover are outlined in this etherpad:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/solum-austin-summit-planning

schedule.title: Release Management: Retrospective and Planning Session
schedule.description:
We will be reviewing the changes we made during Mitaka and gathering feedback about what went well and what needs more work. Then we will go over additional changes already planned for Newton.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-relmgt-retrospective-and-planning

schedule.title: App Catalog: Work session
schedule.description:
Work sessions are for App Catalog contributors to discuss implementation details and making quick progress over specific issues, in a small work group environment.

(Continuing the conversation from previous session)
Work sessions are for App Catalog contributors to discuss implementation details and making quick progress over specific issues, in a small work group environment.

Topics we plan to cover:
Support for more projects and their associated assets (including Magnum, Solum, TOSCA, Mistral, and any others)

What does an OpenStack Application look like? (packaging, distribution, dependency management, etc. - any examples in the wild other than glance images?)

What's in a name? Do we need to address the ongoing confusion that we're different from Murano :) ?

Continuing to cover any outstanding topics from our conversations with the Horizon team

Etherpad

schedule.title: Is OPNFV Just an OpenStack Extension?
schedule.description:
OPNFV has just released Brahmaputra which is the first major version. Openstack is the dominant component in OPNFV. But what does that mean? Which OpenStack modules are the important ones within OPNFV and why are they chosen? Which components did OPNFV add to OpenStack when building up its architecture? This session will provide some insights how OPNFV is using OpenStack and how OpenStack modules need to interwork with other components to create a carrier platform for NFV.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.

videos.name: Is OPNFV Just an OpenStack Extension?

schedule.title: CloudKitty: Planning future changes
schedule.description:
In this session we will discuss future changes needed in CloudKitty. We'll meet with other developers/company willing to contribute or do feature requests. If you want to influence the future of CloudKitty, it's your chance to speak.


This session is mainly to plan and discuss priorities and see who wants to contribute to the project.


etherpad link

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
schedule.description: We'll talk about whatever we want here.

schedule.title: App Development in a Dockerized Universe
schedule.description:
As our development projects grew, and our team more distributed, we needed a better way to onboard new developers, consistently deploy new environments, and predictably test subcomponents.

To solve our requirements, we turned to containers in order to manage each component and orchestrate the full application stack. Although there is a moderate learning curve for new team members, these tools have given us a huge benefit in lowering the level of effort for each development iteration, vastly increased reproducibility, and have radically simplified the ease in product installation.

In this session, we will walk attendees through our development and deployment lifecycle using Docker containers deployed into an OpenStack cloud. We will describe how each stage has been improved, the challenges we encountered, and the solutions that we’ve implemented.

videos.name: App Development in a Dockerized Universe

schedule.title: Deep Dive into Elastic Load Balancing Using Octavia
schedule.description:
THE CHALLENGE -- how to cost-effectively provide Load Balancing as a Service (LBaaS) for cloud workloads. Customers expect the cloud to support their elastic workloads no matter how large they grow. On one hand, services, such as LbaaS, must have the resources to handle huge workloads; on the other hand, for the many customers that have very small workloads, the (free tier) LBaaS has to use as little resources as possible.

THE SOLUTION -- Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) An Elastic Load-Balancing Service dynamically aligns the load-balancing resources with the customer's elastic workloads. Use OpenStack Octavia to implement.

THE "DEEP-DIVE" -- Octavia provides an operator-grade reference implementation of LBaaS for OpenStack, utilizing HAProxy. Octavia supports various load balancing configurations to support different levels of performance, scalability, and availability.  Octavia's new  N+1 (a.k.a active-active, all active) configuration provides the basis for an Elastic LBaaS.

videos.name: Deep Dive into Elastic Load Balancing Using Octavia

schedule.title: Containerizing Network Services
schedule.description:
The increasing interest around application containers is driven by increasingly sophisticated applications, often distributed across data centers. Containers hide the complexity of the underlying infrastructure, allowing applications to integrate seamlessly and transparently.

With the increasing maturity of OpenStack Neutron, and increasing support for a large number of services, in this session we examine how SDNs can leverage the container technology for supporting "as a Service" components, which as opposed to application containers we call service containers. Such services include load balancing, virtual private networking, or dynamic routing in the upcoming Mitaka release, and for which containers can be a key component for any distributed SDN solution that wants to guarantee highly availability across physical hardware.

videos.name: Containerizing Network Services

schedule.title: Enterprise Working Group - Working Session
schedule.description: This is the working group Newton cycle kick-off meeting. Agenda details can be found here: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enterprise_WG_Austin_Meetup

schedule.title: Ops: Informal Meetup
schedule.description:
Following the success of the same event at the Tokyo summit, all this is is a place and ops will gather here. Apparently good things will happen, but it's completely unstructured and informal, so who knows what will happen!

The Ops Meetup, organized by the User Committee, is a track comprised of collaborative, working sessions for people who are operating OpenStack clouds (and contributors who want to hear from them). The purpose is to share knowledge and best practices among cloud operators, as well as provide feedback based on experience running OpenStack. There will be no formal presentations, and a moderate level of knowledge around running OpenStack is assumed. If you're just starting out, the Operations Track of the conference will be much more friendly!
